subject: Re: Problems running JUnit
msgSnippet: My X class is in the same directory as my TestX class, both in C:/build/classes Just made for this junit test. Magnus
messageBody:
My X class is in the same directory as my TestX class,
both in C:/build/classes

Just made for this junit test.

Magnus

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lasse Koskela" <lasse.koskela@...> wrote:
>
> On 10/23/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:
> > so I have to write:
> > import X;
> >
> > in the top of the TestX.java ?
>
> It depends. In what package is your "X" class defined? If it's the
> default package, then no import statement is needed. If X is defined
> in, say, package "com.acme" then you need to "import com.acme.X;".
>
> There's probably some Java tutorial out there in the internet that
> tells you more about the magic of import statements.
>
> Lasse
>
